title: Question 61

children: A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for multiple episodes of diarrhea and emesis with significant abdominal pain and distension. She was hospitalized 3 days ago for
associated pyelonephritis and treated with ceftriaxone. She takes no other medications.

On physical examination, the patient is confused. Temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, pulse rate is 125/min, and respiration rate is 24/min. The abdomen is distended, with decreased bowel sounds and tenderness to palpation but no guarding. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory.

Oral vancomycin (by mouth or nasogastric tube) plus intravenous metronidazole are recommended for fulminant CDI. If an ileus is present, rectal instillation of vancomycin should be considered. Patients with fulminant disease warrant surgical evaluation as well.

The 2021 Infectious Diseases Society of America and Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America clinical practice guideline for CDI suggests oral fidaxomicin or oral vancomycin (
) to treat an initial episode of nonsevere or severe CDI. Nonsevere CDI is defined as a leukocyte count of less than 15,000/µL (15 × 10

/L) and a serum creatinine level less than 1.5 mg/dL (133 µmol/L); severe disease is associated with a higher leukocyte count or serum creatinine level. If both agents are unavailable or intolerable, then oral metronidazole (
) can be used but only in nonsevere disease.
